TITLE: Consider making less food and composting leftovers this Thanksgiving, experts say
SUMMARY: A prep cook at MoMo's restaurant in San Francisco drops apple skins into a food-scrap recycling container in 2009. Composting, a process that converts organic materials into nutrient-rich soil, can help reduce the amount of trash dumped into landfills

SUMMARY: In this undated photo provided by RETO Media is the house featured in the Steven Spielberg film

SUMMARY: Photographer Nan Goldin poses after being awarded Commander in the Arts and Letters Order, in Paris, June 27, 2006

TITLE: The U.S. wants to slash carbon emissions from power plants. Natural gas is in the way
SUMMARY: To close America's remaining coal plants, many industry analysts believe the country needs natural gas to ensure reliable energy supplies until cleaner options like battery storage are widely available

TITLE: REAL ID enforcement is delayed again to 2025
SUMMARY: People wait at the New York State Department of Motor Vehicles office at Atlantic Center in the Brooklyn borough of New York on December 18, 2019. Angela Weiss/AFP via Getty Images

TITLE: What we know about the attack on two North Carolina power substations
SUMMARY: A gunfire attack on two electrical substations in Moore County, N.C., knocked out power to the region, including to stoplights in the town of Southern Pines

SUMMARY: Chelsea Banning watched in disbelief as authors like Neil Gaiman and Margaret Atwood told her of their experiences with low turnout at book signing events

TITLE: A congressional report says financial technology companies fueled rampant PPP fraud
SUMMARY: A congressional report found financial technology companies, or fintechs, largely fueled PPP loan fraud. Bluevine, a fintech noted in the report, told NPR it adapted to threats of fraud better than other companies mentioned. SOPA Images/SOPA Images/LightRocket via Gett

TITLE: Some streets closed during the pandemic to allow pedestrians will remain car-free
SUMMARY: Cyclists and pedestrians enjoy Rock Creek Park's Beach Drive in Washington, D.C., on Nov. 26. The road has been closed to motorized vehicles since April 2020, and officials have decided to keep it closed to vehicles indefinitely

TITLE: In a year marked by inflation, 'buy now, pay later' is the hottest holiday trend
SUMMARY: New research tackles the central question about "buy now, pay later": Does it encourage people to overspend

TITLE: From Buzz Iceclear to Clearopathra, snowplow naming gains traction around the country
SUMMARY: A PennDOT plow truck clears roads in northeastern Pennsylvania following snowfall of up to two feet on March 14, 2017, in Scranton. Around the country, people are participating in contests to give local snowplows clever names

TITLE: Oregon's LGBTQ community worries that a new law will keep them from obtaining guns
SUMMARY: Mia Rose, a trans person of color and former licensed firearms dealer, holds her custom-built AR-15 rifle in her home in Eugene, Ore., on Dec. 12, 2022. Celeste Noche for NPR

TITLE: Oregon Gov. Kate Brown explains why she commuted all of her state's death sentences
SUMMARY: Oregon Gov. Kate Brown, pictured in San Francisco in October, commuted the sentences of all 17 people on death row on her way out of office

SUMMARY: Counter-protesters carrying Black Lives Matter flags walk past a group of Trump supporters at the Michigan State Capitol building in November 2020 in Lansing, Mich

SUMMARY: Retail spending dipped in November compared to October, as holiday sales bit into inflation

SUMMARY: A marble bust of Chief Justice Roger Taney is displayed in the Old Supreme Court Chamber in the U.S. Capitol on March 9, 2020
